comments.body: Maybe include details about what 'value' is, why 'debugLabel' might be useful (it's included in various toStrings), how to use lowerBound and upperBound, whether those have to be ordered (is upper<lower ok?).
on line 62: `Returns a [Animated<double>]` -> an

The `lowerBound` and `upperBound` properties are an alternative to creating a Tween. The properties are most commonly used with simulations with the `fling()` function.

In general, using upperBound and lowerBound shouldn't be mixed with Tweens.
Does the base class not have `@mustCallSuper`?  If not, should we introduce it here?
It's complicated. The base class is actually a mixin. I tried adding @mustCallSuper the other day but it ends up being a bit of a mess, iirc.
Oh, looks like I cleaned the mess up, too, and we do have it now. La la la.
Done.
Can you make the toString resilient against a null _ticker? (e.g. notice that and add DISPOSED to the details, and don't show info about the ticker)

This value is typically used by repeating animations, like indeterminate progress indicators, to prevent the AnimationController from ticking at all?

Also: since (as far as I can tell) this value means that we don't do anything when the device requests that animations be disabled, it would be helpful to say as much.
I renamed the enum to "preserve" since this captures the concept better, scaling was more related to the time dilation stuff.
some of these AnimationBehaviors are presumably AnimationControllers?
we should get this via the TickerProvider or via the Ticker, not directly from the binding, so that it is easier to override.
nit: inconsistent spacing (space after `{` but no space before `}`)
this and the 0.05 constant earlier are presumably intentional related. We should derive them from the same constant.
why not just multiply the duration here rather than pass the value and then have the constructor multiply?
also wherever you call into SemanticsBinding.instance, handle the case of it being null (which might happen if someone has code that they haven't updated to mix in the new binding).
`assert(reverse != null)`

Given the _initialT computation, `assert(max > min)`. However:  AnimationController allows lowerBound == upperBound, so (sadly) it's necessary to deal with that special case and only `assert(max => min)` (as well as  max <= upperBound and min >= lowerBound
Did that 👍
also need to assert that max  <= upperBound and min >= lowerBound.
Also done 😉
Reading this file in order. So far I'm a bit skeptical about adding new APIs at this low level since it seems like it's the same as [reverse] and the curve can come from the Animation being driven.

So, I mean, the core of the issue is that it is necessary that the animation direction is ```reverse```, and there's no way to do that using a custom animation with the functions that we currently have and the way the whole animation system is set up for the route, at least as far as I could tell. Tho maybe I'm missing something?
Talked offline. This is ok since we're already driving animation controllers non-linearly via calls to .fling etc.
This change is a trivial 80 character line limit correction in keeping with the style guide, and to also trigger the relevant framework tests confirming tryjob execution.
